paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Does TRAPPIST-1 b retain any atmosphere under strong stellar irradiation from its M dwarf host star, given its very short and likely tidally locked orbit?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Observed planetary system
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: One rocky exoplanet with phase-resolved thermal spectra
datasets_or_cohorts.description: JWST MIRI low-resolution spectroscopy observations of TRAPPIST-1 b, capturing thermal emission variations over a complete orbital phase curve and spectral structure around the 15 um CO2 band.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Bare-rock null hypothesis
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmosphere-free model assuming minimal heat redistribution, where absorbed stellar energy is immediately reradiated from the dayside without atmospheric transport mechanisms.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmosphere model incorporating significant greenhouse gas absorption, particularly targeting the 15 um spectral band where CO2 creates a characteristic spectral signature.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Oxidized atmospheric composition scenario with weaker CO2 signature constraints, representing a potential alternative atmospheric chemistry for tidally locked rocky planets.

major_limitations: This is a single-planet study and does not establish atmospheric prevalence across all M-dwarf rocky planets.
Retrieval assumptions including circulation models, opacity priors, and cloud treatment affect quantitative posteriors and conclusions.
Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral features and introduce uncertainties in atmospheric detections.
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current JWST MIRI dataset, limiting complete atmospheric characterization.
